headline: Irish Cream Crème Brûlée
description: This crème brûlée has a touch of Irish cream, making it even more special!
name: Irish Cream Crème Brûlée

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat oven to 300 degrees F (150 degrees C). Place 6 ramekins on a towel set in a roasting pan at least 3 inches deep.

Stir together cream and sugar in a saucepan over medium heat, and cook until very hot, stirring until the sugar dissolves. Whisk together egg yolks, vanilla, and Irish cream until combined. Slowly add 1/3 of the hot cream, whisking it in 2 tablespoons at a time until incorporated. Once you have incorporated 1/3 of the cream, you can stir in the remaining hot cream without fear of the mixture curdling.
Pour custard into the ramekins, then fill roasting pan with boiling hot water to come halfway up the sides of the ramekins. Bake in preheated oven until set, 50 to 60 minutes.

Once the custard has set, place ramekins on a wire rack, and allow to cool to room temperature, about 1 hour. Cover, and refrigerate until cold, about 4 hours. Custards may remain refrigerated until ready to serve.

Unwrap the custards, and sprinkle about 1 teaspoon of superfine sugar onto each. Gently shake the custards so the sugar coats the entire top surface, then tip the custards to a 45-degree angle and shake off excess sugar.

Using a small hand torch, melt the sugar by making short passes over top of the custards with the flame not quite touching. Continue melting the sugar until it turns deep brown. Once the sugar has melted and turned to caramel, the cold custard underneath will harden the sugar into a crispy crust. Serve immediately. Alternatively, the sugar-dusted custards may be browned underneath the broiler in the oven.

review.reviewBody: Very easy to make and I don burn it like I used too.
Okay so I used 3 tbsp of dulce de leche caramel instead of the Irish creme liqueur / vanilla...and it was incredible. I don’t know how I can ever top this dish.
Turned out fantastic! Great Irish Creme flavor (I used McCormick because that's what I had). Didn't change a thing.
It was a good creme brulee but didn’t taste like Irish cream at all. I used Carolyns, maybe the brand of liquor changes the flavor? Going to try it with amaretto next!

Creme brulee has long been my favorite dessert, and I'm so grateful to this recipe for inspiring me to buy a culinary torch and give it a go. It was actually really easy to make, and absolutely delicious. The torched crust was amazing, but I think I enjoyed the creamy, rich custard even more. We could definitely taste the Irish creme and didn't think it got lost in the dish at all. I initially considered adding more but am glad I didn't. 

**Note for myself: Due to the terribleness of my oven, I had to do an additional 25 minutes at 325 before the custard set.

I used a *bit* more Irish Cream than the recipe called for just because the equivalent of half a tablespoon per ramekin didn't seem like much, and I like boozy desserts. Kept the rest of the ingredients as listed, and the cook time was spot on. Tasted delicious. I'd never made creme brulee before; I don't think I melted the sugar quite enough with the blow torch - it did crust, but the crunch with the spoon wasn't quite as satisfying as I'd hoped. Practice makes perfect, will be making this one again for sure.
thin

Hubby loved it! I made just two small changes: instead of 6 egg yolks I used 2 whole eggs and 2 yolks, and increased the liqueur to 1/4 c. Tip: check the custards at 40 minutes, I left mine in for 50 and they were just on the verge of being overcooked, but were ok.
This was so good! I recommend to everyone. Easy instructions. Followed exactly.
love them! I used half and half vs heavy cream and not added any Irish cream either and they turned out great. thank you for sharing.
Super easy and delish recipe...made it for school project with my youngest - it was a hit!
Super easy to make and very good. I found if you don't have any Bailerys you can use any other creamed liqueurs and they work just as well.
This recipe was amazing and a hit with my co-workers. Perfect amount of Irish creme, creamy, outstanding! Note: I did not use the towel.
Absolutely delicious!
Great recipe, I haven’t made crepe brûlée much but it was easy to follow and came out great

This was a great hit at a dinner party I had last month. I ended up using the broiler, but can easily see how a torch would more evenly distribute the brown topping over the custard. Loved the Irish Cream flavor - definitely not too strong. Will definitely make again.

I did the recipe word for word. There was enough glaze left to save in a small Ball jar. When we had the cake on the second day I put the cup of glaze in microwave and heated it just to warm. Then as each person got a slice they poured that luscious sweetness over their slice......YUM!

I have made this several times. Lately I started substituting vanilla sugar for the white sugar and used vanilla paste in place of the extract. Makes the flavor phenomenal!

I have also made this with bourbon cream instead of Bailey's and think I like it even better!

Cheers!
Super easy and turned out great it was a big hit!
Loved it. Making it again this year as it has become a New Year's Eve favourite with my friends.
This is so creamy and delicious, we loved it. My daughter said it is one of her favorite desserts.
I don't put and irish cream, but I do increase the vanilla. After I caramelize the sugar on top, I add fresh berries when they're in season. DELICIOUS!!!
The recipe is delicious ! I will make again.
Loved it

Followed the recipe as written but used home raised Duck Eggs (larger yolks!) and vanilla paste (great flavor due to the vanilla beans).

I must have whisked too much because even though I poured the creme mixture evenly into each of the ramekins, each ramekin had lower and lower levels of creme once baked. I believe the very first pour had mostly whisked foam and as I poured the last, that one had mostly creme mixture.

Even with trying the two most creme-volumned cremes, my husband & I could not finish each of our dishes...they were soooo rich...we could only eat half of each! Possibly because of the duck egg yolks or possibly our pallets are changing for really rich, sweet desserts. But, the other halves went back into the refrigerator for another go at it tonight. I also think the remaining cremes will probably be tough since each has less and less creme in them.

Amazing recipe. I have used the same recipe with substitutes for the Irish crème, like Godiva Liquor. It is outstanding with any flavor you want to use. I just use the same amount of liquor with whatever flavor I want to go for.

I've made creme brulee before but wanted something festive for New Year's dessert. I tasted the custard (before baking) and noted that it tasted so sweet even though I cut the sugar by 1-2 TBSP. The Bailey's Irish cream is so sweet on it's own. I would consider going w/ 1/4 cup sugar (not 1/3) but I like my desserts less sweet generally.
To off-set the sweetness, I added about 1/4 tsp salt (the Real Salt brand) and it really balanced the excessive sweetness. It tasted like salted caramel! We'll see how it tastes after we do the brulee...
Ok update! I increased to 5 stars because the taste was perfect so I take back what I say about the 1/4 sugar. I think 1/3 cup is ok (maybe less 1-2 TBSP). This recipe was met with rave reviews and I will be making it again. I hope it becomes a tradition!
I have made this the last 4 years at Christmas. Recipie never disappoints. The only thing I would add is a glass of ice and pour the remaining Baily's over it until the cook is done...

I made it exactly as written except I doubled the recipe to make 8 servings
For a dinner party. Everyone loved it. It has just the right amount of Irish cream flavor, not overwhelming. It was very creamy custard. Yum.
Easy, dreamy and delicious. Couldn't taste the Bailey's much though. I'm making it again today... adding MORE Bailey's! :-)
Best Crème brûlée ever!

Excellent recipe. I was looking for a recipe without vanilla extract, as I didn't have any, and this was fabulous with no vanilla (I omitted), and I used Torani Hazelnut Syrup instead of the Baileys. Yum and easy.
Made it as written. Next time I'd check it about 7-8 mins earlier so it'd be just a bit softer, however this was one of our favorite renditions of Creme Brûlée.
Blend sugar for superfine sugar topping. Run through sieve before baking

Can't believe how easy this is. Irish cream adds great flavor. Wish I would have removed the frothy/bubbly top before putting in oven as it creates a bubbly crust which doesn't change the flavor, just the texture.
I liked this recipe better than other's have seen. I usually leave out the Bailey's. It is really easy and delicious.

This was my very first attempt at cremè brulee & Im SO glad i choose this recipe! It was for 10 other people & it was a hit! I used small little mason jars & then sous vide them instead of using the oven, but same concept
Simple and delicious. We could not taste get even a hint of the Irish Cream so I will have to compare with a batch made with out it to see if there is a difference for me.
Easy as the recipe says and if you want to change it up add a little amaretto or any wonderful cordial to the mix for added flavor.
Super easy! Super good! Just happened to have heavy cream left over and bam! Easy and done! And YUM!

I'll definitely make this again. Loved the custard. I'm still trying to perfect getting a good crisp on the sugar. That's the only reason I gave it a four which is my fault rather than the recipe. I didn't change a thing and it was so easy to make.

Not sure what the hype is all about with this recipe. I made it exactly as stated with quality ingredients and while the texture was great (near perfect, I would say), all I tasted was egg yolk. Perhaps the Irish Cream is just throwing the flavor off for me, but I think I will try this again with fewer yolks (maybe 4 or 5) and perhaps a bit more sugar or natural vanilla.
Perfect as is.

Great recipe. Served this instead of cheesecake for Easter dinner. When the family heard there will no cheesecake, they were all disappointed. The cream brulee disappeared quickly. Followed the recipe and it was perfect. Make it the night before and refrigerated. Torched the top before my guests arrived and decorated it with raspberries and a sprig of mint before serving. This was a great make ahead desert. Nothing to do when the guests arrived. Thanks for making entertaining hassle free.

Texture was nice and creamy. Very tasty. Couldn't really taste the Irish cream though. Also it makes a really small amount. I am not sure what size ramekins make 6 but I made 4 average ones and only about 1/2 full. I could have made just 3 good size ones.
Half rated a 5 the other half a 4. We made with Vanilla paste, not extract. Otherwise as written.
wow, followed the recipe exactly and was very satisfied. DELICIOUS!!
I make this recipe all the time and it always comes out wonderful. This time I substituted the Irish cream with Chambord and served with a side dollop of honeyed whip cream.
Made this for St. Patrick's day dessert! If we could have licked the dishes, we would have done so! As other's suggested, I doubled the Irish Cream Liquoir! A keeper!!!

My ramekins are too big, I think, & the servings were too deep. Use shallower ramekins next time. And try traditional creme brulee without the Irish cream. Got to use my new kitchen torch, though!! Very cool!

I made this recipe for Sunday dinner. The flavor was great and everyone loved it. As for the Bailey's taste, it was lost in the dish, nobody cold tell it was in there and I used more than what it called for just so we could taste it. Great Brulee but forget the Bailey's. I followed the recipe exactly but just added more Bailey's. Thanks for a great desert though!!
Very good recipe! Very hard to mess up. I do make either 1.5 times or double the recipe to fill my dishes. Always get rave reviews!
love it!
I followed this recipe exactly and it was amazing. Honestly, I would much rather have this homemade creme brûlée than any of the restaurant ones I've tried.

Very good, but with only a subtle hint of Irish Cream flavor. Would have liked to see it more pronounced, so I'd suggest adding more. Rather than superfine sugar I used the coarser, demerara sugar. My ramekins were shallow rather than the 6 oz. custard type ramekins and needed just 25 minutes of baking time, so the specified baking time is only approximate!
This was amazing. I followed the recipe exactly as written and browned the top under a broiler. I served it for company and they loved it. I will definitely make this again.
This recipe was delicious! Do try to caramelize the sugar with a blow torch, I followed someone's advice by putting these under a broiler, and it just didn't work out.
Amazing.Best creme brulee ever!

Had to substitue Kahlua in place of the Irish Cream as I discovered my Irish Cream was no good, but this turned out fantastic. I was a bit leery as the last time I made Creme Brulee was 6-7 yrs ago and I made either vanilla or chocolate and figured a box of pudding was just as good - that recipe also had you melt the sugar on the stovetop then pour/drizzle over the custard - it just wasn't the same crispy topping that you would get than if you used a torch. 
This recipe was super easy and super tasty - I highly reccomend adding a liquer or some other flavoring of your choice.(Instead of going plain vanilla - but that is my personal prefference) 
This was a hit with my parents, my husband and I as well as my younger thirteen year old brother and my two kids ages 7 and 4 - a recipe for all ages! Everyone loved it! I was almost hoping one of the kids wouldn't like theirs so I could have more!
Next time I will try it with Irish Cream, but I can bet it will be great either way!

Excellent recipe! It's the first time I've prepared creme brulee and it turned out almost perfect. "Almost" is there because it was a bit too sweet to our taste. I'll try to use 1/4 cup sugar next time.
It was really good, lengthy to make but worth it!
Easy to make and tastes delicious!
Made this for my husband's special b-day dinner and it was so amazing. The only change I made was to use Amaretto instead of Irish Cream.
TIP: To get superfine sugar just use regular sugar and put in a blender for just a short time and you will have fine sugar instead of buying it in the store.
Delicious, great texture, and easy to make.

These were pretty good. Bought a torch for this recipe (I'd been wanting one for quite a while). Could imagine any number of liqueurs in this. The Irish cream was pretty subtle. Thanks for the recipe.
Really easy and delicious recipe. I used 2% instead of heavy cream and it worked out well.

I've never made Creme Brulee before and this came out perfectly. I didn't add the Irish Cream this time. To check if it is "set", I used tongs to pick up a ramekin add 'jiggled'. When only the center moved a little, it was "set" - about 55 min.

Spectacular recipe. We were looking for something special to make for our New Years Eve dinner and did a test run of this. Turned out fantastic and has been added in to the rotation for "guest desserts".
Easy Recipe and DELISH! A must have in the Dessert Tab. Another option for the Irish Creme is Amaretto!

Great, easy recipe, and it can be scaled down if, like me, you only have four ramekins. Quick tip for those who hate waiting for the froth to subside: pour the cream mixture into the ramekins, then light your hand torch and quickly whisk it over the tops. The froth will disintegrate.
good, moist and strong flavor. First bite is a tad bit disappointing, but it gets better as you eat it
Wonderful recipe...super easy and tastes AWESOME!!
very rich.
This is a simple and wonderful creme brulee recipe. It's a good choice for any cook trying creme brulee for the first time.
Oh my gosh. This was AMAZING. So simple and easy, and the Irish Cream adds an extra kick. So delicious. Better than any restaurant.

So easy and delicious. The amount of Irish Cream
is just right.
good, and even better after sugar and broiled
I would suggest adding more than the recommended amount of Bailey's.

The literal translation of this rich dessert is "burnt cream" and this recipe is a good standard and works well. In French kitchens a Salamander is used to burn the sugar and is still my preference since I don't like the idea of a "fuel" torch close to food. When lining the pan with a towel soak the towel first otherwise you may absorb all the water before the custard sets, putting too much heat on the side of the dish.

This was so delicious, I wish I had made larger portions! After asking Santa for a kitchen torch for a few years now, I finally got one and made this for New Year's. I didn't have Irish cream on hand so used up the end of some chai liqueur. It was amazing!
Try it with different types of dessert-y liquor! Kahlua is great for the coffee lover. :)
I made this without the alcohol and it came out perfect!
Wonderful and easy.

Wife loved it and she has it all the time when we go out to eat. I did not use the Irish Creme and kept the vanilla at the same amount as the directions. I only used 5 egg yolks due the extra large Costco eggs I was using.(they are monster eggs) I had previous tried the allrecipe creme brulee post using the double boiler. This recipe turned out waaaay better than the double boiler recipe. We had some blackberries so we places a few on top to add some color and taste. Good stuff!!!
Very good! Super, super easy! I happen to have carmal flavored Baileys and it was great!
I loved these, but wish they had a little more "irish cream flavor" in them... I halved the recipe and was able to fill 4 small creme brulee dishes.

Now this was incredible!!!!! What a great recipe. really important to follow the directions, especially when tempering. 3 tablespoons of the hot cream mixture at a time to the egg mixture and wisk at the same time. the creme brulee was so creamy and what an incredible flavor. I made 12 ramekins and our guests went crazy. They were really impressed when I pulled out my torch that I purchased at bed bath and beyond just for this dish. Used raw sugar to make the candy carmelized coating. Thank you for a truly incredible desert.

Learning how to make Cream Brulee in cooking school was one of the first custard style desserts we had to learn to make. I could make them in my sleep. I didn't have access to my old recipes so I used this one. I'm not sure what happened, but it lost almost half it's volume when it was baked. I'm going to have to start over again and try a different methoid.
Perfect! I love this recipe it was so quick and easy and tasted delish! It works just fine with out the liquor (since I'm too young...)
I made 75 of these for my wedding - instead of cake. Easy to make, and I was able to make them almost a week in advance. A HUGE hit

I made this today and it turned out perfectly. Tricks: Slowly bring the sugar and cream to temperature. It doesn't take long, I think medium heat may be too high. Also, slowly pour the cream mixture with the egg yolks. There will be a considerable amount of foam once all of the cream has been mixed; this is where straining it before it goes in the ramekins is so important. If it is not strained there will be a nasty layer on top. Update: I think I have perfected the recipe. Instead of using 1/3 cup of sugar use 1/2 cup. Also, instead of using vanilla extract using a vanilla bean. Split the vanilla bean in half, scrape out the inside, and place both in the heavy cream. Heat the creme and vanilla in a medium sauce pan. In a mixing bowl combine the egg yolks with the sugar.
This was so yummy!!!!! Will make again.
The best dessert yet!
Really good--I followed the recipe exactly.

This recipe was very good, but a little time consuming and not quite as good as another recipe on allrecipe.com. I used 3 Tbsp of Irish Cream and it gave it a subtle flavor. I followed the instructions for 50-60 min baking time so I set the timer for 40 minutes and they were totally overdone. Next time i'll try 25-30 minutes. I had no problems with the eggs scrambling.

My 14 year old daughter made this for a french class assignment... we sub'd Caramel Bailys for the Irish Cream and our ramekins were a bit deep so it took a little longer cook time but this turned out excellent. Broiled the sugar on top under the broiler and it turned out perfect!

WOW I have to wholeheartedly say, this is probably the best recipe I've pulled from this site. Hubby and I were at a fancy restaurant the other day and had some superb creme brulee, so of course I wanted to try at home. This is even better. It's a tad time consuming, but not really all that difficult. I heated the cream and sugar to about 140 degrees with no problems. I whisked briskly but tried to not get it frothy. I had no lumps or froth. The hardest part is dealing with the water bath, transferring everything in and out of the oven. Mine made 4 medium and 3 small ramekins. All set up absolutely perfect. Husband had a fun time torching the sugar in the raw we used on the top. Which by the way, tasted great but was probably too course to melt exactly right. Simply unbelievable texture and taste! The irish cream with the creme brulee is divine and melds perfectly. Reviewers aren't joking, the irish cream flavor comes through very well. I might even lower the amount if I make it again. I will definitely make this again the next time I have a craving, or if I truly want to impress someone at a dinner party.

One word...heavenly!! I didn't have heavy cream, only whipping cream, so I used that instead, and I feel like that made it not so heavy of a custard. Everyone loved it...hubby even had seconds!!!! Thanks for the fantastic recipe :)
